form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Ms. Warren (for herself, Mr. Leahy, Mr. Wyden, Mr. Durbin, Mr. Menendez, Mr. Sanders, Mr. Brown, Mr. Whitehouse, Mrs. Shaheen, Mrs. Gillibrand, Mr. Franken, Mr. Blumenthal, Mr. Schatz, Ms. Baldwin, Mr. Murphy, Ms. Hirono, and Mr. Markey) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

form.official-title: To amend the Fair Credit Reporting Act to prohibit the use of consumer credit checks against prospective and current employees for the purposes of making adverse employment decisions.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Equal Employment for All Act of 2015.

section.header: Use of credit checks prohibited for employment purposes

subsection.header: Prohibition for employment and adverse action
subsection.text: Section 604 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. 1681b) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a)(3)(B), by inserting within the restrictions set forth in subsection (b) after purposes;
by redesignating subsections (b) through (g) as subsections (c) through (h), respectively; and
by inserting after subsection (a) the following new subsection:

subsection.header: Use of certain consumer report prohibited for employment purposes or adverse action

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3), a person, including a prospective employer or current employer, may not use a consumer report or investigative consumer report, or cause a consumer report or investigative consumer report to be procured, with respect to any consumer where any information contained in the report bears on the creditworthiness, credit standing, or credit capacity of the consumer—

subparagraph.text: for making an adverse action, as described in section 603(k)(1)(B)(ii).

paragraph.text: The prohibition described in paragraph (1) shall apply even if the consumer consents or otherwise authorizes the procurement or use of a consumer report for employment purposes or in connection with an adverse action with respect to the consumer.

Notwithstanding the prohibitions set forth in this subsection, and consistent with the other sections of this Act, an employer may use a consumer report with respect to a consumer in the following situations:

subparagraph.text: When the consumer applies for, or currently holds, employment that requires national security clearance.

paragraph.header: Effect on disclosure and notification requirements
paragraph.text: The exceptions described in paragraph (3) shall have no effect upon the other requirements of this Act, including requirements in regards to disclosure and notification to a consumer when permissibly using a consumer report for employment purposes or for making an adverse action against the consumer.
